+[[constraintStreamsConditionalPropagation]]
+=== Conditional propagation
+
+Conditional propagation enables you to exclude constraint matches from the constraint stream based on the presence or
+absence of some other object.
+The following example penalizes computers which have at least one process running on them:
+
+[source,java,options="nowrap"]
+----
+    private Constraint runningComputer(ConstraintFactory constraintFactory) {
+        return constraintFactory.from(CloudComputer.class)
+                .ifExists(CloudProcess.class, Joiners.equal(Function.identity(), CloudProcess::getComputer))
+                .penalize("runningComputer",
+                        HardSoftScore.ONE_SOFT,
+                        computer -> ...);
+    }
+----
+
+Note the use of the `ifExists()` building block.
+On `UniConstraintStream`, the `ifExistsOther()` building block is also available, useful in situations where your
+`from()` constraint match type is the same as your `ifExists()` type.
+
+Conversely, the `ifNotExists()` (and `ifNotExistsOther()` on `UniConstraintStream`) are available to achieve the
+opposite effect:
+
+[source,java,options="nowrap"]
+----
+    private Constraint unusedComputer(ConstraintFactory constraintFactory) {
+        return constraintFactory.from(CloudComputer.class)
+                .ifNotExists(CloudProcess.class, Joiners.equal(Function.identity(), CloudProcess::getComputer))
+                .penalize("unusedComputer",
+                        HardSoftScore.ONE_HARD,
+                        computer -> ...);
+    }
+----
+
+Here, only the computers without processes running on them will be penalized.

timeline.bodyText:
I'd argue that's not the most important difference between join() and ifExists().
This is the real difference:
[a1, a2, a3].join([b1, b2], someCondition) gives up to 6 matches.
[a1, a2, a3].ifExists([b1, b2], someCondition) gives up to 3 matches.
